column4: I'd like to run a 64bit virtual machine, how can I find out if my mother board supports 64-bit virtualization? I looked in the BIOS and couldn't find anything about it.
to check if your CPU has virtualization (64bit virtualization?) "$ cat /proc/cpuinfo" (Intel verify "vmx" is present, for AMD verify "svm" is present)
will "vmx" be present if it supports it, or if it is enabled?
if it shows up in cpuinfo - that means your cpu supports it - enable in whatever Virtualization software you are using.
oh, I don't enable it in the bios if it's supported?
bios? doubt it - but in say VirtualBox there is an option to enable that support for each VM.
fyi kvm (linux kenel virtual machine sw) requires that your cpu have that support (qemu, which kvm is sorta based on does not)
`cat /proc/cpuinfo|grep vmx` gives me nothing, guess my mb doesn't support it :(
you are running "cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep vmx" with the spaces right?  did you also try "cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep svm"?
actually looks like the spaces don't matter ;)
yeah, I tried both . . don't get anything back. :( pooh.
that is unfortunate.  CPU Virtualization is VERY cool.
but, like, I can still do virtualization, right? just without 64 bit?
yes but not kvm!  VMware or Virtualbox or Qemu will work fine - just not at full speed :(  & some OSs/systems won't work
awe, man! why'd I get this mb then?  ugh, this totally stinks!
I use kvm at work . . but here at home I'm trying virtualbox.  but man, I just built this system.  wonder why my friends recommended this mb if it doesn't support virtualization.
you "might" even be able to run 64bit in VBox?  probably does require the virtualization but not sure - i know you can run 64bit on 32bit hosts
well, thanks for your help, even if I found out something I'm totally upset about now :( lol
